Recipe for Potato Dumplings (Varenyky)
Ingredients:
For the dough:
Wheat flour – 500 g
Water – 200 ml
Egg – 1
Salt – 1 tsp
For the filling:
Potatoes – 1 kg
Onions – 2
Lard or butter – 50 g
Salt – to taste
Ground black pepper – to taste
Preparation steps:
Making the dough:
Sifting the flour: Sift the flour into a large bowl.
Making the dough: Add salt and the egg to the flour. Gradually pour in the water, constantly stirring. Knead the dough until it becomes smooth and elastic.
Resting the dough: Wrap the dough in plastic wrap or cover it with a towel and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Preparing the filling:
Boiling the potatoes: Peel the potatoes, cut them into large pieces, and boil until tender in salted water.
Preparing the onions: While the potatoes are boiling, finely chop the onions. Sauté the onions in lard or butter until golden brown.
Making the potato puree: Drain the potatoes and mash them. Add the sautéed onions, salt, and pepper to taste, and mix well.
Forming the dumplings:
Rolling out the dough: Roll out the dough into a thin sheet about 2-3 mm thick. Use a glass or cutter to cut out circles approximately 7-8 cm in diameter.
Forming the dumplings: Place a spoonful of potato filling on each circle of dough. Fold the dough in half and pinch the edges tightly to seal the dumplings.
Cooking the dumplings:
Boiling water: Bring a large pot of water to a boil, add salt.
Cooking the dumplings: Gently drop the dumplings into the boiling water, stirring carefully to prevent sticking. Cook until done (approximately 5-7 minutes after they float to the surface).
Serving:
Removing the dumplings: Remove the dumplings with a slotted spoon and place them on a plate.
Serving: Serve the dumplings hot, optionally drizzling with melted butter, sour cream, or sautéed onions.
Enjoy your meal!

The DLC for this game is much cheaper now than it was on release. A major benefit since 3 is now the focus for all the new content.    
It runs much smoother and has lower system requirements than it's successor. 
It's a smaller map and easier to understand. The narration at the beginning is better, if you are interested in the lore. The narration is similar to Shogun 2. 
The art style is much more gritty than it's more cartoon-y successor. 
The AI is more responsive and fluid. You have to worry less about a unit not following your orders like in 3. The enemy AI is more aggressive. 
Total War Academy still has all the old YT videos for you to look at to get an idea of what means what and how things work.
There's less factions than it's successor and it has less endgame crisis but it's more of a loreful experience in return. 

Play 3, if you want an excellent multiplayer experience. Play 2, if you want to immerse yourself into the world of WHFB.

So I own all 3 games in the TW:Warhammer series and all of the DLC's. I've been playing since the first one launched back in 2016, so buying DLC over the last almost 10 years wasn't as daunting as someone new looking at getting into these games. 

I have recently gone back to this game because I truly believe it is the strongest entry of the series and I only say that because it built upon everything great that the first game already had. TWW 3 at this point just feels like 2 steps back in terms of quality. Every update they push out, 2 or 3 game-breaking bugs pop up. Also, the UI in this game and the 1st installment are impeccable compared to the over-simplified and "toned-down" UI in the 3rd game. TWW3 honestly just looks and feels inferior. 

Onto the factions: Yea the different Chaos factions are cool and do I miss not being able to play them? Sometimes. However, Between this game and the first, you get all of the lore-heavy good vs baddie races from the Warhammer universe. 

Let's talk about Immortal/Mortal Empires game mode now. In this game, the map still feels very large - down to regions. The color pallete and textures of the overhead map look great as well. In TWW3, however, the world looks and feels smaller; i.e. regions were shrunk by the developer AND they made the terrain look slightly cartoony almost. Hard to explain but there was definitely an art choice made that makes it look worse IMO. 

I stand by my opinion that if you want the best TW:Warhammer experience, then wait for this game and the 1st to go on a heavy sale and stop there. TW:Warhammer 2 is the best in the series to date.

Greetings!  Finally getting around to Total War:  Warhammer 2; even though I loved the original I was unsure what the second really provided that the first didn’t.  Did I find this to be true or does this add so much to be worth the new edition?  Let’s Discuss!

Groundhog Day:  Unlike most RTS games this series doesn’t reinvent itself or really change all that much.  With that in mind, I’ll be reviewing this assuming you’ve already the previous title.  Same great game, yes really.  As best I can tell it’s literally the same game.  Maybe there were updated graphics?  Unsure but all the content is here (except one major thing which was addressed by a free DLC).  

All that Glimmers:  There is a ‘story’ campaign that limits the factions involved and has a story but don’t expect a cinematic masterpiece here.  I’d like to believe playing the other factions has a different perspective from the campaign, I’m sure it does, but I didn’t take the time and probably won’t.  Mainly because I just don’t really like the factions involved (except for the Tomb Kings, which tangentially are, probably because they didn’t want a DLC faction to be excluded from the game).

Pointy Ears are Dumb:  I’m just not a fan of the elf factions.  But seriously, the main issue with this is the lack of content.  As best I can tell this is a few faction packs with an expanded map; which adds more focus onto the open sea but lack any real sea combat (you apparently both paddle over to land to fight).  If you think about it pragmatically the game is worth the value with the new factions and the expanded map.  I can just see how someone might be slighted by the lack of a real ‘new game.’  Oh, one thing that really bothers me is you still can't disable DLC.  Or at least let me disable anything post launch.  It's annoying to see all this content I'm playing against but can't play with.   At this point the game should have a checklist type system, maybe even let me pick what factions are even involved.

Overall, it’s worth the purchase.  Chances are if you are a Total War fan you’ll just buy all three of these and call it a day.  I’d recommend waiting for a sale of course as they are often and seem to be 50%+.  Enjoy!

Um, yea. Total War. It never stops.
When I play other Total War games, there is part of me that want to follow historical accuracy or cultural history. Not with this one.

And that is a pro! Speaking of which:
-Hero characters are done right. They are valuable units but not unstoppable, and their customisation is meaningful to the game-play.
-There is a lot of variety in how you can play. Certain strategies fit certain factions better, but nothing is off the table.
-The battles can be very detailed and immersive. 
-Most of the time you'll do better than the autoresolve, even clinching absurd scenarios. Its a fun challenge if not a bit "ughh I have to fight this one manually no matter what"
-The story is more than good enough.

Cons:
-It aint the easiest game to run at higher graphical settings, even to this day.
-It's one of those games where a couple of DLC is required to make it truly re-playable and varied. And there's LOTS of DLC.
-If you don't like to read, the learning curve is very steep.
-AI at difficulties other than "normal" is either notoriously incompetent or does outright cheating
-Total War: Warhammer III is out with just about the same ammount of DLC. If you like this base game, you are probably better off spending your money there.

Oh and don't bother with the "Direct X 12" setting. It's never worked properly!

Happy conquering :)

This game is honestly awesome! I’ve been playing as the High Elves, and I really enjoy the new mechanic where your general can lead a one-man army. It’s something I’ve never seen in older Total War games like Shogun 2, and it makes battles way more dynamic and personal. At first, I thought sending a single hero into battle was risky, but it’s actually super fun once you get used to it.

What I also like is how each faction feels different now — the new systems really push you to play in your own style instead of following the same pattern every campaign.

That said, I do agree with some other players: city battles still need more work. Fights in unwalled cities don’t really feel like you’re inside a town, unlike Total War: Attila where the urban layout made battles look more immersive. Even without adding full defensive systems, a more city-like environment would make a big difference.

Still, despite that, this is easily one of the best Total War experiences I’ve had so far — and I hope CA keeps improving it in future updates!

A couple years ago I bought all 3 Total War: Warhammer games in a decently discounted bundle and started playing them in order. I didn't go through the ups and downs that most people who bought around release went through, so enjoyed all 3 games (in hours, roughly: 50, 100, 1000 - respectively), and each one was better than the last, despite any changes to campaigns, difficulties, skills & technologies. Since TW:WH3 was the beset of the 3 with many "quality of life" improvements, I mostly played that after finishing with 1 & 2. After lots of time, and getting fed up with the bugs and other annoyances, I decided to give TW:W2 another try. Let's see.

It has performance issues like stutters / bad 1% lows. I'm on a 5060 Ti, not high-end, arguable if it's mid-tier, and playing on 4K which is clearly not the best for the hardware, BUT it runs worse compared to TW:W3, even though I have REALLY lowered the settings for TW:W2. The unit counts are smaller even on ultra, and I play on lower settings too (medium/low), compared to every setting being on high for TW:W3 and having nearly double the unit counts.

There are some nice things though. I like how the campaign maps way more. I only saw two maps (one siege and one field battle) and they were different than the maps I've seen in TW:W3, not sure if I'd say they're better or worse, but I am very tired of the TW:W3 maps, so maybe the old TW:W2 maps are a breath of "fresh" air,

The QoL improvements from TW:W3 are really noticeable too. If you've played TW:W3 and want to try TW:W2, you'll likely be annoyed and may enjoy it less. If you're new, maybe consider getting TW:W3 instead, or better yet look for another game since...

TW:W3 is absolutely riddled with bugs, which why I wanted to try TW:W2 again. Based on what I remembered, TW:W2 didn't have any major bugs and it was pretty smooth, and everyone keeps saying that it is a "finished game". Guess my surprise when on turn ~4 I play a siege battle only to discover that some of the same bugs as TW:W3 are here too (siege & gate bug, units dispersing, pathfinding). On one hand, it shouldn't have surprised me, because the same company is developing roughly the same game on roughly the same engine. On the other hand, some of these bugs in TW:W3 didn't seem like they were there 1-2 years ago, so it *feels* (I don't think it actually happened) like these errors were "backported" somehow to TW:W2. Obviously, CA doesn't care very much about fixing bugs in TW:W3, so they won't care about TW:W2 having bugs either.

So definitely don't buy this unless for whatever reason you there is some locked content you want for TW:W3... but again, why give CA your money? I didn't buy any DLCs, and I'm likely never buying another TW game ever again. I *almost* believe Ubisoft deserves your money more than CA. Maybe you can try the latest Anno or Europa Universalis games? Or not, up to you.

I enjoyed the game for a few years. You want a decent machine to play on, as the loading between battles (start and finish) was significant. I finally upgraded my machine and the loading is now a non issue.  This made me consider buying WH3 at the last sale and the other expansions I don't have. However, l watched some youtube videos, and legendoftotalwar dropped a video of the state of the game. LOTW got me into the game to start with. All the bugs and issues still in the game made me reconsider, and I did a summary of the the issues I have in WH2.

I play as the dwarfs, but own most of the other DLC to support the game. 

- your allies bug out.
         - you can select targets for your allies to attack. However, my allies bypass the last remaining region they don't have in a province and go attack a region 4 provinces away to stop me claiming it and getting the regional buff. They were not at war with the faction that owned the settlement when they departed, yet at war with the targeted faction.
         - if your allies are at war with a faction, and the enemy gets confederated, the ally refused my offer to join war against the "new" enemy. So now I have an enemy as a neighbour, and my ally does nothing. I can take the settlement, but now I own 1 out of 4 regions. I can abandon the region, but my ally wont take it, and a 3rd party will claim it. I cant do nothing with the settlement as the growth is so slow. I am a top 5 power rank, the enemy and ally are between 40 -> 60 power rank.

- Race legendary lords refuse to confed with me. I have over 400 rating with them, they are down to their last settlement and just get wiped out over the end turn. I had tried to confed them the previous 20 turns when they had 5 settlements and several armies. They kept getting weaker and then just died. I can never get the "dream team" going.

- The underway - a 3 way unique feature (dwarves, skaven, orcs). The path is a bumpy road, uneven ground, random small hills. The dwarves cant see over it and you have to check each unit of thunderers / iron drakes line of sight, otherwise they stand there and do nothing if their view is blocked (the units wont advance to attack). There is no way to smooth out the underway = owning the province you're in etc. An army of miners to spend 5 turns clearing up the path etc.
        - due to the units lack of height, and the line of sight issues, there is no alternative aside from the basic quarrellers and grudge throwers / flame cannon. The humans have mortars. What a weapon this would be in the dwarves roster. 
        - cannons and organ guns - line of sight issues again.
        - the cannon in some settlement maps - can't shoot over the wall, yet the front gate is right next to the city square. A useless unit.  

- The "fun" was removed. I use to enjoy putting several Master Engineers into an army to boost the range of units through their skill tree. Having a few flame cannons out range other artillery was fun. Iron drakes with flame throwers reigning hell down on enemy forces. LOTW did a doom stack video going up against elves with dragons and destroying the army, next patch, the skill tree was reworked. The skaven were still able to stack their range skill buffs.

- skaven summoning - there is no counter other than to have your infantry/heros stand in amongst your artillery. Your front line is standing in your back line, and having a lack of speed, you cant get your front line back to the front line. You need to destroy these summons ASAP, otherwise they can destroy your artillery even while being attacked by your other units.

- skaven settlements - every battle is the same map lay out for a settlement with walls. There are 2 non walled settlement maps with the same issues as underway battles, lumpy ground. 

- unit balance - my elite iron breakers can lose to a basic skaven infantry unit. It makes playing a balanced army pointless.

Its a game and I want to have fun. But each patch removed a positive feature to where the game is a grind for the sake of being a grind. If you want the game to be lore friendly, cool, but make the units lore abilities even across the game. 

WH3 has a few features, buy settlements to have an alternative with incompetent ally choices. But there are too many bugs and non fun mechanics in the game to want to spend any more money on the franchise.

I would like to continue playing this game, however, in the state it is now, I do not recommend it.

I enjoyed the game for a few years. You want a decent machine to play on, as the loading between battles (start and finish) was significant. I finally upgraded my machine and the loading is now a non issue.  This made me consider buying WH3 at the last sale and the other expansions I don't have. However, l watched some youtube videos, and legendoftotalwar dropped a video of the state of the game. LOTW got me into the game to start with. All the bugs and issues still in the game made me reconsider, and I did a summary of the the issues I have in WH2.

I play as the dwarfs, but own most of the other DLC to support the game. 

- your allies bug out.
         - you can select targets for your allies to attack. However, my allies bypass the last remaining region they don't have in a province and go attack a region 4 provinces away to stop me claiming it and getting the regional buff. They were not at war with the faction that owned the settlement when they departed, yet at war with the targeted faction.
         - if your allies are at war with a faction, and the enemy gets confederated, the ally refused my offer to join war against the "new" enemy. So now I have an enemy as a neighbour, and my ally does nothing. I can take the settlement, but now I own 1 out of 4 regions. I can abandon the region, but my ally wont take it, and a 3rd party will claim it. I cant do nothing with the settlement as the growth is so slow. I am a top 5 power rank, the enemy and ally are between 40 -> 60 power rank.

- Race legendary lords refuse to confed with me. I have over 400 rating with them, they are down to their last settlement and just get wiped out over the end turn. I had tried to confed them the previous 20 turns when they had 5 settlements and several armies. They kept getting weaker and then just died. I can never get the "dream team" going.

- The underway - a 3 way unique feature (dwarves, skaven, orcs). The path is a bumpy road, uneven ground, random small hills. The dwarves cant see over it and you have to check each unit of thunderers / iron drakes line of sight, otherwise they stand there and do nothing if their view is blocked (the units wont advance to attack). There is no way to smooth out the underway = owning the province you're in etc. An army of miners to spend 5 turns clearing up the path etc.
        - due to the units lack of height, and the line of sight issues, there is no alternative aside from the basic quarrellers and grudge throwers / flame cannon. The humans have mortars. What a weapon this would be in the dwarves roster. 
        - cannons and organ guns - line of sight issues again.
        - the cannon in some settlement maps - can't shoot over the wall, yet the front gate is right next to the city square. A useless unit.  

- The "fun" was removed. I use to enjoy putting several Master Engineers into an army to boost the range of units through their skill tree. Having a few flame cannons out range other artillery was fun. Iron drakes with flame throwers reigning hell down on enemy forces. LOTW did a doom stack video going up against elves with dragons and destroying the army, next patch, the skill tree was reworked. The skaven were still able to stack their range skill buffs.

- skaven summoning - there is no counter other than to have your infantry/heros stand in amongst your artillery. Your front line is standing in your back line, and having a lack of speed, you cant get your front line back to the front line. You need to destroy these summons ASAP, otherwise they can destroy your artillery even while being attacked by your other units.

- skaven settlements - every battle is the same map lay out for a settlement with walls. There are 2 non walled settlement maps with the same issues as underway battles, lumpy ground. 

- unit balance - my elite iron breakers can lose to a basic skaven infantry unit. It makes playing a balanced army pointless.

Its a game and I want to have fun. But each patch removed a positive feature to where the game is a grind for the sake of being a grind. If you want the game to be lore friendly, cool, but make the units lore abilities even across the game. 

WH3 has a few features, buy settlements to have an alternative with incompetent ally choices. But there are too many bugs and non fun mechanics in the game to want to spend any more money on the franchise.

I would like to continue playing this game, however, in the state it is now, I do not recommend it.
